How to include a metapod model of your robot in your code

In the remainder of this section, it is assumed that you are using CMake as a compilation environment.

For a continuous integration of your model in your code, a good practice is to generate automatically the C++ code for your robot based on the URDF model.
To do that you should add the following line to the CMakeLists.txt of your project: 

   include(path_to_your_metapod_install/share/cmake/metapod.cmake)

Then at the CMakeLists.txt where you need to use the model, you should add: 

   set(model_name "the_name_of_your_robot")
   add_sampleurdfmodel(${model_name} ${urdf_path} ${data_path} ${gen_dir}$ )

where

  • the_name_of_your_robot is the prefix of your robot model file,
  • urdf_path is the directory where the ${name}.config file and the file metapod_license_file.txt are located.
  • gen_dir is the location where the headers and the sources files are generated.

If you do not specify ${urdf_path}, ${data_path} and ${gen_dir} then they are set to the following default values:

  • urdf_path: ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/data/${name}.urdf
  • data_path: ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/data/
  • gen_dir: ${CMAKE_CURRENT_DIR}/include/metapod/models/

To force cmake to create the C++ headers and code related to your robot model, you should add or modify the TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES of your target: 

   TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(your_target metapod_${model_name} ${the_other_libraries})

To see how to modify the code depending on your target, please look at the tutorials page.
